title: Question 01
body: Question 01: Block ciphers are used in symmetric cryptography to encrypt and decrypt data. They operate on blocks of a fixed length (usually 64 or 128 bits). To encrypt some data, you could split it into block sized chunks and simply encrypt them separately. What which of the following properties are true?
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}} then select Submit.

_items.text: Patterns in the data will show up, which can impact security
It will be easy to calculate the key

title: Question 04
body: Question 04: Block ciphers can be used in different modes, such as "Counter" mode. Which of the following are properties of this mode?
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}} then select Submit.

_items.text: It is commonly called CTR mode
The counter value must be kept secret to avoid key compromise
Transmitting the counter value along with the data is secure and mitigates packet loss
Reusing the same counter value twice is safe
If part of the cipher stream is reused, it can be used for known plaintext attacks
It is robust against packet loss

title: Question 03
body: Question 03: Which of the following block cipher modes provide authenticated encryption?
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}} then select Submit.

title: Question 02
body: Question 02: Usually block ciphers have an encrypt and a decrypt function. Can a block cipher with only an encrypt function be useful?
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}} then select Submit.

_items.text: Yes, it can be used for MAC functions
Yes, it can be used for modes like CTR mode
Yes, it can be used because encryption and decryption are usually the same
Yes, it can be used for digital signatures
Yes, it can be used for PRNGs

title: Question 05
body: Question 05: Is hashing data with MD5 a good way of proving that it was sent by the authorized sender?
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}} then select Submit.

_items.text: No, it is not a good way
Yes, but SHA256 should be used, because MD5 is not secure anymore
Yes, it is a good way

title: Question 06
body: Question 06: Which of the following properties are true for MACs?
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}} then select Submit.

_items.text: They require both parties to share a secret key
They require the use of public/private key pairs

title: Question 07
body: Question 07: Which of the following techniques fall under the category of symmetric cryptography?
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}} then select Submit.

title: Question 08
body: Question 08: Encoded data is usually:
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}} then select Submit.

title: Question 09
body: Question 09: Cryptographically hashed data is usually:
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}} then select Submit.

title: Question 10
body: Question 10: Encrypted data is usually:
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}} then select Submit.

title: Question 11
body: Question 11: In asymmetric cryptography, you have a public and a private key. Which of the following statements are true?
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}} then select Submit.

_items.text: A public RSA key is used to sign messages, while the private key used to verify signatures
The public key should be distributed to other parties
The private key should be distributed to other parties
The private key is used for decrypting data, and the public key is used to encrypt data.

title: Question 12
body: Question 12: When both encrypting and compressing data, the preferable order and reason is:
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}} then select Submit.

_items.text: First encrypt, then compress, otherwise the encryption key may be leaked
First compress, then encrypt, otherwise the the encryption key may be leaked
First encrypt, then compress, otherwise the compression will be ineffective
First compress, then encrypt, otherwise the compression will be ineffective

title: Question 13
body: Question 13: In a man-in-the-middle attack:
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}} then select Submit.

_items.text: The attacker steals one party's private key to eavesdrop on all communications
The attacker intercepts encrypted messages in the middle of the connection and modifies them
The attacker presents their own public key to both parties, claiming it to be the other party's key
The attacker inserts themselves between two parties and impersonates them to each other

title: Question 14
body: Question 14: Salts are used when securely hashing passwords. Which of the following is true?
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}} then select Submit.

_items.text: Salts act as an encryption password on the server side and should be kept secret.
Salts ensure that an attacker has to attack each password individually.
Salts are used to switch between different hashing algorithms.
Salts do not need to be kept secret.
Salts make it much harder to decrypt hashed passwords.

title: Question 15
body: Question 15: When verifying a user's password in a server based application, ideally:
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}} then select Submit.

_items.text: Additionally, the password is also hashed on the client side before being transmitted to the server.
The stored password on the server side is decrypted and compared to the provided password.
A cryptographic hash function (SHA-1) is applied to the password and compared with a stored hash.
A salted password hashing function is used to decrypt the password on the server side, to compare it with the provided password.
A salted password hashing function is applied to the provided password and compared with a stored result.

title: Question 16
body: Question 16: If a method to authenticate a message provides non-repudiation, it means that:
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}} then select Submit.

_items.text: The sender of the message cannot claim not to have sent the message.
The sender of the message cannot be forced to admit having sent the message.

title: Question 17
body: Question 17: When a file stored on a hard drive or SSD is deleted:
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}} then select Submit.

_items.text: Depending on the filesystem, upon deletion, meta data may get overwritten, making the data non-trivial to recover, even if it is still on the disk.
Securely deleting data is difficult and active field of research.
It is marked as deleted, but the data is still on the disk.
Recovering the data is trivial, since only a single flag needs to be flipped back.
Overwriting a file by writing another file with the same name securely overwrites its contents.

title: Question 18
body: Question 18: The Diffie-Hellman algorithm is used to:
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}} then select Submit.

title: Question 19
body: Question 19: Compared to asymmetric cryptography, symmetric cryptography has the following properties:
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}} then select Submit.

_items.text: Quantum computers could fully break its security
To communicate, both parties need a shared secret
To remain secure in a world with quantum computers, keys of twice the length should be used
Keys are usually longer than those in asymmetric cryptography

title: Question 20
body: Question 20: Doing cryptography in the browser with JavaScript is common these days but there are some issues:
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}} then select Submit.

_items.text: There is no way to ensure that key materials does not remain in memory
It provides no security benefit, because the connection is usually secured by HTTPS
There is no way to securely generate random numbers
The server may send poisoned code that could send sensitive data back to it

title: Question 21
body: Question 21: Does encrypting data prevent attackers from modifying the data in targeted ways?
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}} then select Submit.

_items.text: Yes, the decrypted data will be gibberish if it was modified
No, but the attacker would have to know the decrypted data first
No, but depending on the way the data was encrypted, no fine-grained modifications can be made
Yes, the decryption will fail if the data is modified

title: Question 22
body: Question 22: According to the pigeonhole principle, hashed data cannot be "unhashed" in the general case, but if your data is very short (1-5 characters), you could hash it and "decode" the hash by brute force search. Would this be a secure way of encrypting short strings of data?
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}} then select Submit.

title: Question 23
body: Question 23: In cryptographic hashing, there is a concept preimage resistance. Which of the following is true?
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}} then select Submit.

_items.text: Preimage resistance means that for a given input, it is computationally infeasible to calculate an output with the same input.
Third preimage resistance means that for a given input and another given output, it is infeasible to calculate a third input with an output identical the the first output.
Second preimage resistance means that for a given input, it is computationally infeasible to calculate a second different input with an identical output.
Preimage resistance means that for a given output, it is computationally infeasible to calculate an input that would produce this output.

title: Question 24
body: Question 24: Digital signatures usually offer the following properties:
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}} then select Submit.

title: Question 25
body: Question 25: To generate cryptographic key material the following sources can be usually reasonably secure:
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}} then select Submit.

_items.text: User input processed through a key derivation function
A cryptographic pseudo random number generator

title: Question 26
body: Question 26: In Python, a dictionary can have duplicate keys.
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}} then select Submit.

body: Question 27: In Python, a list can have duplicate entries.

body: Question 28: Which of the following Python packages can be used to create and manage a Python virtual environment?

title: Question 29
body:
Question 29:
        [({'uuid': '00000000',
        'timestamp': 1618047000,
        'temp': 5.33,
        'clouds': 10,
        'wind_speed': 10,
        'wind_deg': 31.0,
        'wind_gust': 4.1,
        'rain': 1.54}, 45.5),
        ({'uuid': '00000000',
        'timestamp': 1618017000,
        'temp': 5.33,
        'clouds': 10,
        'wind_speed': 10,
        'wind_deg': 31.0,
        'wind_gust': 4.1,
        'rain': 1.54}, 0.0)]

The above Python code snippet represents:
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}} then select Submit.

_items.text: A list of two tuples; where each tuple contains two elements, a floating point number, and a dictionary (in that order).
A tuple of two lists; where each list contains two elements, a dictionary, and a floating point number (in that order).
A list of two tuples; where each tuple contains two elements, a dictionary, and a floating point number (in that order).
